title-group.article-title: Impact of Experiences With Racism on African-Descent Persons’ Susceptibility to Stereotype Threat Within the United Kingdom

author-notes.corresp: Stanley O. Gaines Jr., School of Social Sciences, Brunel University, Uxbridge UB8 3PH, UK Email: stanley.gaines@brunel.ac.uk

abstract.p: The present study examines the impact of experiences with individual, institutional, cultural, and collective racism on susceptibility to stereotype among African-descent persons within the United Kingdom (n = 103). Results of hierarchical multiple regression analysis indicated that (contrary to hypotheses) experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism were not significantly or marginally related to susceptibility to stereotype threat when entered together in Model 1. However (consistent with hypotheses), experience with collective racism was a significant positive predictor of susceptibility to stereotype threat after controlling for the effects of experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism in Model 2. Moreover (and unexpectedly), once experience with collective racism was added, experience with cultural racism emerged as a marginal negative predictor of susceptibility to stereotype threat. Implications for the continuing relevance of Erving Goffman’s symbolic interactionist theory and construct of stigma, along with Claude Steele’s construct of stereotype threat, to the field of Black psychology is discussed.

body.p: The third edition of the Handbook of Social Psychology (Lindzey & Aronson, 1985) was the first edition to include substantive coverage of symbolic interaction theory, a sociological theory that emphasizes the extent to which individuals not only may determine their own actions but also may directly or indirectly instigate social change through their actions (Stryker & Statham, 1985). One of the best-known proponents of symbolic interaction theory was Erving Goffmam, whose The Presentation of Self in Everyday Life (1959) dealt primarily with efforts by social actors to convey positive impressions to social perceivers. Although social actors’ motive to convey positive impressions to social perceivers is distinct from social actors’ motive to view themselves positively, the two motives do not necessarily contradict each other (e.g., most individuals think and feel positively about themselves and are likely to communicate that information to other persons; Robins & John, 1997).

The fourth edition of the Handbook of Social Psychology (Gilbert, Fiske, & Lindzey, 1998) was devoid of any substantive coverage of Goffman’s (1959) symbolic interaction theory in general but did include substantive coverage of Goffman’s (1963) concept of stigma, or an attribute that is devalued within a particular society (Crocker, Major, & Steele, 1998). In Stigma: Notes on the Management of Spoiled Identity, Goffman (1963) contended that evidence of social actors’ membership in racial, religious, and/or national minority groups within a given society (e.g., skin color, religious ornaments, linguistic accent) constitutes one or more “tribal stigmas” that put those social actors at a distinct disadvantage when trying to convey positive impressions to social perceivers from racial, religious, and/or national majority groups.1 Even though evidence of membership in a racial, religious, or national minority group is not inherently negative, the stereotyping that such evidence triggers in the minds of many (if not most) members of racial, religious, and/or national majority groups can undermine minority group members’ attempts at impression management.

In the present study, we examine the impact of experiences with various aspects of individual, institutional, cultural, and collective racism on susceptibility to stereotype threat—a concept developed by Claude Steele (1997) and derived from Goffman’s (1963) theorizing with regard to the negative social and psychological consequences of stigma—among persons of African descent within the United Kingdom. Previous research on stereotype threat has focused primarily on the academic performance of African-descent persons in the United States, partly because of the popularity of Steele’s research within the United States (e.g., Blascovich, Spencer, Quinn, & Steele, 2001; Deaux et al., 2007; Steele & Aronson, 1995) and partly because of the popularity of a different research tradition regarding intergroup relations operating within the United Kingdom (i.e., research on contact between members of experimentally created groups based on Henri Tajfel’s (1981; Tajfel & Turner, 1979) social identity theory and drawing on Gordon Allport’s (1954) contact hypothesis from The Nature of Prejudice (for a review, see Crisp & Abrams, 2008). However, given the increasingly multiethnic composition of the U.K. population (e.g., members of racial minority groups currently comprise approximately 8% of the U.K. population; U.K. Office of National Statistics, 2004), we believe that the time is overdue for research on stereotype threat within the United Kingdom (see Gaines & Reed, 1994).

sec.title: Susceptibility to Stereotype Threat Among African-Descent Persons Within the United Kingdom
sec.p: Stereotype threat refers to the anxiety and, potentially, impaired performance resulting from stigmatized individuals’ belief that they will be evaluated in a domain where members of their group historically have been expected to perform poorly (Steele, 1997). For example, within the United States, women historically have been expected to perform poorly on mathematics tests relative to men; when women are reminded of this expected sex difference, women tend to underperform relative to men in actual mathematics testing situations (Carr & Steele, 2009; Pronin, Steele, & Ross, 2004; Spencer, Steele, & Quinn, 1999). In addition (and especially relevant to the present study), within the United States, persons of African descent historically have been expected to perform poorly on academic tests relative to persons of European descent; when African-descent persons are reminded of this expected racial difference, African-descent persons tend to underperform relative to European-descent persons in actual academic testing situations (Blascovich et al., 2001; Deaux et al., 2007; Steele & Aronson, 1995).

To what extent do findings with regard to racial stigmatization and stereotype threat generalize from the United States to the United Kingdom? Surprisingly, few large-scale, quantitative studies of racial stigmatization and stereotype threat have been published in British journals; the studies that have been published (e.g., Marx & Goff, 2005; Osborne & Walker, 2006) generally have been conducted using American, rather than British, samples. Thus, our empirical basis for generalization essentially is nonexistent. However, results of a series of small-scale, qualitative studies by Howarth (2006) suggest that racial minority group members’ experience of stigmatization—if not stereotype threat (which Howarth did not directly examine)—is a common phenomenon in the United Kingdom. Assuming that racial stigmatization and stereotype threat tend to covary (Steele, 1997), we anticipate that stereotype threat will be a relevant issue for many, if not most, African-descent persons in the United Kingdom.

So far, we have implied that all African-descent persons in the United States or, for that matter, in the United Kingdom will experience stereotype threat. Indeed, the overwhelming majority of studies regarding racial stigmatization and stereotype threat appear to be guided implicitly (and, perhaps, explicitly) by such a premise (Crisp & Abrams, 2008). However, not all members of a socially stigmatized group experience stereotype threat to the same degree, within or across situations. We use the term susceptibility to stereotype threat to refer to individual differences within a stigmatized group regarding the tendency to experience stereotype threat. Rather than manipulate stereotype threat (as is usually the case in studies of stereotype threat), we opted to measure susceptibility to stereotype threat as an individual-difference variable with a range of scores along a continuum (following Marx, Stapel, & Muller, 2005).

sec.title: Impact of Experiences With Individual, Institutional, and Cultural Racism on African-Descent Persons’ Susceptibility to Stereotype Threat Within the United Kingdom
sec.p: Why are some African-descent persons more susceptible to stereotype threat than are other African-descent persons within a given society? Janet Helms (2006) hypothesized that the more often African-descent persons experience anti-Black racism in its myriad forms, the more likely it is that African-descent persons will be susceptible to stereotype threat. Drawing on James Jones’s (1972) distinction among prejudice at various levels, Helms (2006) reasoned that repeated experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism will make African-descent persons increasingly likely to experience anxiety and to underperform when they are placed in situations that evoke societal stereotypes regarding African-descent persons’ ostensibly limited academic aptitude (see also Jones, 1997). Individual racism refers to stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination on the part of specific persons toward racially stigmatized individuals; institutional racism refers to stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination on the part of specific organizations toward racially stigmatized individuals; and cultural racism refers to stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination that might not be attributable to particular persons or organizations but that nonetheless occur within a given society and can affect racially stigmatized individuals via mass media and other forms of communication.

James Jones’s (1972) conceptualization of individual, institutional, and cultural racism not only expanded on Allport’s The Nature of Prejudice (1954) but also represented a major contribution to the literature on race relations during the early 1970s. However, it was not until the mid- to late 1990s that Shawn Utsey developed the original Index of Race-Related Stress (IRRS; Utsey & Ponterotto, 1996) and the Index of Race-Related Stress–Brief Version (IRRS-B; Utsey, 1999) to measure individual differences in African-descent persons’ experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism. Results of subsequent studies by Utsey and his colleagues indicate that experiences with racism are negative predictors of African-descent persons’ subjective well-being within the United States (e.g., Utsey & Constantine, 2006), although the specific experiences with racism that are significantly related to well-being may vary across studies (e.g., Utsey, Chae, Brown, & Kelly, 2002; Utsey, Payne, Jackson, & A. Jones, 2002) and may be moderated by other variables (e.g., Utsey, Lanier, Williams, Bolden, & Lee, 2006). Research is scant regarding the links between individuals’ experiences with racism and subjective well-being in the United Kingdom.

Helms’s (2006) individual-differences model identifying individual, institutional, and cultural racism as positive predictors of susceptibility to stereotype threat shows promise as a means toward understanding the circumstances under which some African-descent persons manage to succeed academically, despite the odds. Given that some American and British psychologists historically have lent support to societal myths regarding African-descent persons’ ostensibly limited academic potential (see Yee, Fairchild, Weizmann, & Wyatt, 1993), empirical tests of Helms’s hypotheses could help debunk those myths. However, to our knowledge, no published study has tested Helms’s hypotheses concerning the impact of individual, institutional, or cultural racism on African-descent persons’ susceptibility to stereotype threat in the United States or in the United Kingdom.

sec.title: Experience With Collective Racism: An Additional Predictor of African-Descent Persons’ Susceptibility to Stereotype Threat Within the United Kingdom(?)
sec.p: So far, we have considered three aspects of African-descent persons’ experiences with racism. However, Philomena Essed (1990) added a fourth aspect of racism—namely, collective racism, or the stereotyping, prejudice, and discrimination on the part of specific groups of persons toward racially stigmatized individuals. This fourth aspect of African-descent persons’ experiences with racism does not appear in either the original edition (1972) or in the revised edition (1997) of James Jones’s classic, Prejudice and Racism.

Several items constitute the subscale of collective racism in the original IRRS (Utsey & Ponterotto, 1996). However, only two items constitute collective racism in the IRRS-B (Utsey, 1999). Utsey and his colleagues have continued to measure collective racism but generally have not commented on the impact of collective racism on subjective well-being or on other variables (e.g., Utsey, Chae, et al., 2002; Utsey & Constantine, 2006; Utsey et al., 2006; Utsey, Payne, et al. 2002).

Unlike individual, institutional, or cultural racism, collective racism does not appear in Helms’s (2006) model of experiences with racism as predictors of susceptibility to stereotype threat among African-descent persons. Given the apparent lack of predictive validity (as distinct from construct validity; see Nunnally & Bernstein, 1994) regarding the collective racism subscale of the IRRS-B, we were not as confident in making predictions concerning collective racism as we were in making predictions concerning individual, institutional, or cultural aspects of racism as positive predictors of African-descent persons’ susceptibility to stereotype threat within the United Kingdom. Nevertheless, we anticipated that if collective racism were to exert any impact on susceptibility to stereotype threat, then the impact likely would be positive.

sec.title: Goals of the Present Study
sec.p: In the present study, our primary hypotheses were that experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism would be significant positive predictors of African-descent persons’ susceptibility to stereotype threat within a U.K. sample. Our secondary, more tentative hypothesis was that experience with collective racism would be a significant positive predictor of susceptibility to stereotype threat, explaining variance in susceptibility to stereotype threat beyond that explained by individual, institutional, or cultural racism. We tested our hypotheses via hierarchical multiple regression analysis (see Cohen, Cohen, West, & Aiken, 2003).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 113 individuals of African descent (49 men, 64 women) participated in the present study. Because of missing data for one or more variables, the final n for the sample was 103 individuals. Among the participants, 37.2% were classified as Black-Caribbean, 56.6% were classified as Black-African, and 6.2% were classified as Black-Other.2 The average age of participants was 28.12 years (SD = 9.36 years).

sec.title: Experiences with individual, institutional, cultural, and collective racism
sec.p: African-descent persons’ experiences with racism were measured via the 22-item IRRS-B (Utsey, 1999). The IRRS-B measures four constructs: (a) experiences with individual racism (6 items), (b) experiences with institutional racism (4 items), (c) experiences with cultural racism (10 items), and (d) experiences with collective racism (2 items). Each item was scored according to a 5-point, Likert-type scale (1 = this event never happened to me, 5 = the event happened to me, and I was extremely upset), with higher scores indicating greater frequencies and greater resulting distress with which individuals experienced racism). Sample items include the following: “Sales people/clerks did not say thank you or show other forms of courtesy and respect (e.g., put your things in a bag) when you shopped at some European-descent/non-African-descent businesses” (individual racism); “You have been given more work, or the most undesirable jobs at your place of employment, while the European-descent/non-African-descent people of equal or less seniority and credentials are given less work, and more desirable tasks” (institutional racism); “You notice that crimes committed by persons of European descent tend to be romanticized, whereas the same crime committed by persons of African descent are portrayed as savagery, and the African-descent persons who committed it, as animals” (cultural racism); and “You were the victim of a crime and the police treated you as if you should just accept it as part of being a person of African descent” (collective racism). Results of reliability analyses indicated that with the exception of the collective racism scale, the IRRS-B scales were internally consistent (Cronbach’s α = .83 for individual racism, .77 for institutional racism, .88 for cultural racism, and .51 for collective racism).

sec.title: Susceptibility to stereotype threat
sec.p: African-descent persons’ susceptibility to stereotype threat was measured via a three-item scale, adapted from Marx et al. (2005). Items included the following: “I worry that my ability to perform well on academic tests in general is affected by my social group membership(s)”; “I worry that if I perform poorly on academic tests in general, then the persons who administer the tests will attribute my poor performance to my social group membership(s)”; and “I worry that, because I know the negative stereotype about my social group membership(s) and academic tests, my anxiety about confirming the stereotype will negatively influence how I perform on the tests.” Items were scored according to a 5-point, Likert-type scale (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree), with higher scores reflecting higher levels of susceptibility to stereotype threat. Results of a reliability analysis indicated that the scale measuring susceptibility to stereotype threat was internally consistent (Cronbach’s α = .69).

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors. Prior to conducting the present study, the first author obtained ethics approval from an appropriate research ethics subcommittee. The present study was conducted in accordance with the Code of Conduct, Ethical Principles, and Guidelines of the British Psychological Society (BPS, 2005). The BPS ethics guidelines are similar to APA ethics guidelines in terms of stringency (see Kimmel, 2004).

Participants were recruited within the West London area, largely (though not exclusively) on the campus of Brunel University. Snowball sampling was used, in which the researchers not only approached acquaintances but also followed leads provided by those acquaintances (Bryman, 2001). Participants read and signed the informed consent document, after which they completed the study surveys and were given a debriefing form.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A matrix of zero-order correlations among experiences with individual racism, experiences with institutional racism, experiences with cultural racism, experiences with collective racism, and susceptibility to stereotype threat among African-descent persons within the United Kingdom are presented in Table 1.3 Results of an a priori power analysis (conducted via G*Power 3.0; Faul, 2006) indicated that, assuming medium effect size (i.e., f2 = .15), p = .05, power = .80, and four predictor variables, the final sample size was more than sufficient to detect genuine effects (Cohen et al., 2003).

caption.p: Zero-Order Correlations Among Experiences With Racism and Susceptibility to Stereotype Threat (n = 103)

fn.p: Note: Variables are as follows: 1 = experience with individual racism; 2 = experience with institutional racism; 3 = experience with cultural racism; 4 = experience with collective racism; 5 = susceptibility to stereotype threat. All correlations with absolute values greater than .19 are significant (ps < .01).

sec.p: Inspection of Table 1 reveals that correlations among scores on all four experiences with racism were positive and significant (ps < .01). In addition, the correlation between scores on experiences with collective racism and scores on susceptibility to stereotype threat was positive and fell just short of statistical significance (p < .06; but see also regression results in the paragraphs below). However, correlations between scores on susceptibility to stereotype threat and scores on experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism were not significant or marginal (ps > .10).

Results of hierarchical multiple regression analyses (conducted via SPSS Version 15.0; SPSS, 2007) were nonsignificant for Model 1. Contrary to our primary hypotheses, experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism were not significantly or marginally related to susceptibility to stereotype threat, separately or together as predictors: R2 increase for experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism = .03, F(3, 99 df) = 1.13, p > .10. Beta weights for experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism in Model 1 are presented in the first half of Table 2.

caption.p: Beta Weights for Experiences With Racism as Predictors of Susceptibility to Stereotype Threat (n = 103)

sec.p: In contrast to Model 1, results of hierarchical multiple regression analyses were significant for Model 2. Consistent with our secondary hypothesis, experience with collective racism was a significant positive predictor of susceptibility to stereotype threat, after controlling for experiences of individual, institutional, and cultural racism as predictors: R2 increase for experience with collective racism = .05, F(1, 98 df) = 4.84, p < .05. Furthermore (and unexpectedly), once experience with collective racism was entered as a predictor, experience with cultural racism emerged as a marginal negative predictor of susceptibility to stereotype threat (p < .08). Beta weights for experiences with individual, institutional, cultural, and collective racism in Model 2 are presented in the second half of Table 2.

Experiences with individual, institutional, cultural, and collective racism accounted for a combined 8% of variance in individuals’ scores on susceptibility to stereotype threat, a percentage that was marginal: F(4, 98 df) = 2.09, p < .09. With p = .05 as the basis for power calculations (obtained via G*Power 3.0; Faul, 2006), the effect size was small to moderate (f2 = .09), and the achieved power was low (power = .64), for Model 2 as a whole. In addition, with p = .05 as the basis for post hoc power calculations (obtained via SPSS 15.0; SPSS, 2007), effect sizes were small (partial η2 = .00 for experiences with individual racism, .00 for institutional racism, .03 for experiences with cultural racism, and .05 for collective racism), and the achieved power was low (power = .06 for experiences with individual racism, .05 for experiences with institutional racism, .44 for experiences with cultural racism, and .59 for experiences with collective racism) for the separate Model 2 predictors.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The most striking result of the present study was the significant positive effect of experience with collective racism on African-descent persons’ susceptibility to stereotype threat in the regression analysis. Not only was this effect significant after controlling for the effects of experiences with individual, institutional, and cultural racism on susceptibility to stereotype threat; but this effect emerged in spite of the low reliability of the scale measuring experience with collective racism. If the reliabilities of the scales measured susceptibility to stereotype threat and (especially) experience with collective racism, then the effect for collective racism probably would have been even higher (see Nunnally & Bernstein, 1994). All in all, African-descent persons’ experience with collective racism is unique among predictors of susceptibility to stereotype threat, possibly because of historical as well as contemporary associations with acts of vigilantism and terrorism by White mobs toward Black individuals in the United Kingdom, the United States, and elsewhere (see Back, 2002).

Unlike the effect of experience with collective racism, the effect of experience with cultural racism on African-descent persons’ susceptibility to stereotype threat did not reach statistical significance. Nevertheless, the marginal negative effect of experience with cultural racism on susceptibility to stereotype threat is worth further consideration. James Jones (1997) noted that within American society, elements of cultural racism coexist alongside elements of cultural antiracism. Perhaps elements of cultural racism and cultural antiracism similarly coexist within British society; the potential for such coexistence suggests that when African-descent persons encounter examples of cultural racism (e.g., encountering yet another showing of the relentlessly stereotypical Gone With The Wind), they may fight back symbolically by actively seeking examples of cultural antiracism (e.g., purchasing the stereotype-challenging Roots for viewing at their leisure, prompting them to turn on the television; see Briley, 2008) and, thus, reduce their susceptibility to stereotype threat.

Experience with institutional racism was unrelated to African-descent persons’ susceptibility to stereotype threat. Given that much of the impetus for the present study came from Steele’s (1997) studies of experimenter-manipulated stereotype threat in educational settings, the lack of a relationship between experience with institutional racism and susceptibility to stereotype threat is surprising. Perhaps, African-descent persons have learned to traverse many, if not most, institutional terrains by anticipating experiences with racism and neutralizing their effects when those experiences occur (no small task in some institutional settings, e.g., the police force; see Cashmore, 2001).

Finally, experiences with individual racism were unrelated to African-descent persons’ susceptibility to stereotype threat. Given the attention that social and personality psychologists historically have paid to expressions of individual racism by European-descent persons in the United States (e.g., Adorno, Frenkel-Brunswik, Levinson, & Sanford, 1950; Allport, 1954; Goffman, 1963), the lack of a relationship between experiences with individual racism and susceptibility to stereotype threat is especially surprising. Perhaps, African-descent persons, whether in the United Kingdom or in the United States, inoculate themselves against individual racism by maintaining a state of constant alertness while navigating their social-psychological environment, thus reducing (if not eliminating) the sting that otherwise would accompany experiences with individual racism—a skill that also may be well developed among those European-descent women who either “marry Black” or who give birth to mixed-race offspring (see Harman, 2010).

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations of the Present Study
sec.p: Certain strengths characterize the present study. First, to our knowledge, the present study is the first study to measure experiences with racism and susceptibility to stereotype threat, whether separately or together, among African-descent persons within the United Kingdom. Second, the significant positive effect for experience with collective racism and the marginal negative effect for experience with cultural racism lend support to Helms’s (2006) argument that individual differences in experiences with racism are relevant to understanding individual differences in susceptibility to stereotype threat among African-descent persons.

By the same token, certain shortcomings characterize the present study. First, given that the magnitude of the correlation between collective racism and institutional racism was somewhat higher than was the reliability coefficient for the collective racism scale, the discriminant validity of the IRRS-B could be called into question (see Kenny, 1985; Seaton, 2003). Second, the achieved power for each of the predictor variables (including experiences with collective racism and with cultural racism) was low, thus raising questions concerning the practical significance of the results (see Sun, Pan, & Wang, 2010).

All in all, we believe that the strengths outweigh the shortcomings in the present study. Regarding discriminant validity of the IRRS-B, the scales measuring experiences with collective racism and with institutional racism were quite divergent in terms of their predictive validity (see Nunnally & Bernstein, 1994). Regarding low achieved power, the low effect size and associated low achieved power for experience with collective racism in particular may have been because of the low reliability for that scale, rather than inherently low practical significance (see Ferguson, 2009).

sec.title: Directions for Future Research
sec.p: Future researchers should attempt to collect longitudinal data on experiences with racism as predictors of susceptibility to stereotype threat among African-descent persons. Given that the present study was limited to data from one point in time, we cannot make definitive statements regarding experiences with racism as causes of susceptibility to stereotype threat (Cohen et al., 2003). Such research could help clarify whether cultural racism attains significance as a predictor of susceptibility to stereotype threat.

In addition, consistent with Helms’s (2006) individual differences model, future researchers should examine academic performance as a consequence of susceptibility to stereotype threat. According to Hunt and Carlson (2007), “There are signs that the debate over racial and gender differences in intelligence is about to begin again” (p. 194). Hunt and Carlson expressed ambivalence toward the manner in which the results of studies of stereotype threat have been interpreted. Nevertheless, Hunt and Carlson acknowledged the constructive role that studies of stereotype threat can play in informing past, present, and future debates regarding race and cognitive ability.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: At the outset of the present study, we noted that Goffman’s (1959) symbolic interactionist theory in general received considerable attention in the third edition of the Handbook of Social Psychology (Stryker & Statham, 1985); whereas Goffman’s (1963) concept of stigma in particular received considerable attention in the fourth edition of the Handbook of Social Psychology (Crocker et al., 1998). In the most recent, fifth edition of the Handbook of Social Psychology (Fiske, Gilbert, & Lindzey, 2010), virtually the only sustained coverage of Goffman’s (1959) symbolic interactionist theory, Goffman’s (1963) concept of stigma, and Steele’s (1997) concept of stereotype threat combined consists of slightly more than one page (Blascovich & Mendes, 2010). As mainstream social psychology increasingly turns its collective attention away from Goffman’s symbolic interactionist theory, we hope that the present article will inspire scholars within the field of Black psychology to continue drawing on Goffman’s theory, especially as reflected in research on stigma and stereotype threat.

ack.p: The authors are indebted to Action Editor Kennet Tyler and two anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments on an earlier version of this article.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

Throughout the present article, we use the term racial group to refer to a socially defined group based on individuals’ presumably shared biological heritage (Markus, 2008). Of course, African-descent persons are defined on the basis of individuals’ presumably shared cultural as well as biological heritage (Jones, 1997)—in short, African-descent persons constitute an ethnic group (Landrine & Klonoff, 1996). However, given that the focus of the present article is on anti-Black racial stigmatization in British and American societies, we deal primarily with the presumably shared biological aspects of African-descent persons’ heritage.

The ethnic classification system used in the present study is identical to the ethnic classification system that the government of the United Kingdom used in the 2001 census (U.K. Office of National Statistics, 2004).

Results of a multivariate analysis of variance indicated that mean scores on the independent and dependent variables did not differ significantly or marginally across the Black-Caribbean, Black-African, and Black-Other subgroups: Wilks’s Λ = .85, F(10, 192 df) = 1.62, ns. Moreover, results of Box’s M test indicated that the correlation matrices among the independent and dependent variables did not differ significantly across the Black-Caribbean, Black-African, and Black-Other subgroups (though the difference was marginal): Box’s M = 55.93, approximate F(30, 611.06 df) = 1.39, p < .09. Overall, we concluded that the means and correlations across the three African-descent subgroups were sufficiently similar to justify combining the data.
